channel.description: Recent content in HTML on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Since its inception some decades ago, the internet has grown into a huge (and complicated) place. To create even a basic website, you need to learn multiple “computer languages”.

item.title: What is HTML?
item.description: HTML means HyperText Markup Language. Well, what does that mean? It’s a markup language, not a coding language. That means it structures content you give it, but doesn’t add “logic” or “style”.

item.title: Tags & Elements
item.description: Earlier, I explained how HTML is a markup language. It marks parts of your content as being something. Like you’d use a marker pen to highlight important parts of a textbook.

item.title: Semantics
item.description: Many courses on HTML don’t talk about this, or leave it until the end. I put it at the start because it’s absolutely the most important thing to learn right now.

item.title: Page Structure: Head & Body
item.description: Every piece of content has two major parts: the content itself, and information about the content. For example, a video has the video itself, but also a title, thumbnail, upload date, etcetera.

item.title: Blocks
item.description: Last chapter, we learned about the first and biggest “structure” in every HTML document: head and body. Now let’s go one step further, to the second largest subdivision you’ll create.

item.title: Paragraphs & Headings
item.description: Most of the internet consists of text. Even primarily image or video based websites, like YouTube, still have loads of text.

item.title: Lists
item.description: Most people think of lists as a visual thing. They think about bullet points in a PowerPoint presentation, or a grocery list with an arrow in front of each item.

item.title: Text Formatting
item.description: Moving on, we’ve now reached pretty much the smallest elements you can give meaning. These are all inline elements, added around small pieces of content.

item.title: Code Formatting
item.description: Once you try to format something related to computers or code, you run into an issue. Your webpage is code, but its content is also code.

item.title: Comments
item.description: Like any computer language, HTML provides the ability to leave comments. Such comments are are completely ignored by the computer—they are for you, the programmer.

item.title: Attributes
item.description: This course has moved from our biggest tags to the smallest ones. But even those are quite limited: you’ve only seen about ~20 tags up to this point, that’s not enough to describe all possible content!

item.title: URLs
item.description: Before we can talk about links, I need to explain how a URL works. Most people only know URLs from the long strings of symbols in the address bar of your browser.

item.title: Links
item.description: The internet isn’t called the world wide web for no reason. From the start, it was designed to be an inter connected network of servers.

item.title: Figures
item.description: The next few chapters will all explain essential elements for displaying media (images, audio, video, …). Though not required—nothing is “required” in HTML—it’s recommended to nest all such elements inside a <figure> element.

item.title: Images
item.description: Images are very straightforward. To add one, use the <img> tag (which is a void element). Without anything else, it obviously doesn’t know what image to load.

item.title: The Picture Element
item.description: The <picture> element allows specifying multiple versions of an image. The browser loads the best one, based on your requirements.

item.title: Audio
item.description: In the old days of the internet, adding audio or video was a pain in the behind. But for a good 10+ years now, these elements are supported everywhere and very, very simple to use.

item.title: Video
item.description: The video tag is very similar to the Audio tag. That’s why this chapter will be very short.

item.title: Tables
item.description: As expected, the <table> element is meant for content that is a table. Tables are complicated, however, so it requires a lot of other tags to add the proper structure.

item.title: Forms I
item.description: Forms in HTML are used to collect user input (and submit it). Interactivity is a huge part of webpages and the internet, which is why we’ll spend several chapters on this topic.

item.title: Forms II
item.description: Last chapter taught you the overall structure of a form: how to create one, how to label inputs, and how to submit the data.

item.title: Input I
item.description: In the previous chapters, I already showed a few ways to use the <input> tag. For example, you use it for the submit button of a form, but also a basic empty text field.

item.title: Input II
item.description: Continuing on last chapter, let’s talk about some more types you can set on the <input> element. These are less common, with the most specific (and thus least common) ones all the way at the end.

item.title: Head I
item.description: At the start of this course, twenty chapters ago, I introduced the <head> and the <body>. Everything after that only handled elements for the body.

item.title: Head II
item.description: I’ve mentioned the other web languages, CSS and JavaScript, many times during this course. I never mentioned how you actually include those other languages in your webpage, once you’ve written code for them.

item.title: Entities
item.description: You are almost at the end of the HTML course. Hopefully, you’ve already tried to built a few websites to test your skills and practice them.

item.title: Conclusion: what now?
item.description: You’ve seen all that HTML has to offer. (Barring some very specific and niche elements or ideas.) The language hasn’t changed much over the past 10+ years.

item.title: Miscellaneous
item.description: I wanted to talk about a few more elements that didn’t fit anywhere else. (And which were too simple or short to get their own dedicated chapter.
